docs.lead_paragraph: What's new when you file your taxes this year? Taxpayers without health insurance will face larger penalties, and those insured by their employers will get a new tax form. There also have been adjustments for inflation, and Congress extended expiring tax breaks, some permanently.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fewer than 1 in 4 high school students who've had sex have ever been tested for HIV, a troubling low rate that didn't budge over eight years, government researchers say. Young adults fared slightly better, although testing rates have declined in black women, a high-risk group.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court, which delivered major rulings in 2012 and 2015 preserving President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law, on Tuesday declined to take up a new, long-shot challenge to Obamacare brought by an Iowa artist.

docs.lead_paragraph: As overdose rates rise, candidates are opening up about the spread of addiction, hoping to connect with voters.

headline.main: Just Saying Yes to the Politics of Drugs
headline.print_headline: Just Saying Yes to the Politics of Drugs

docs.abstract: Emma Roller Op-Ed article observes epidemic of drug overdoses in New Hampshire is likely behind Republican presidential candidates' willingness to open up about their families' struggles with addiction; notes dramatic shift from tough stance on drugs and drug sentencing that has been typical among Republicans since presidency of Ronald Reagan.
docs.snippet: As overdose rates rise, candidates are opening up about the spread of addiction, hoping to connect with voters.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health plans offer women a variety of incentives to be screened for breast cancer even when scientific guidelines recommend against it.

headline.main: Insurer Rewards Push Women Toward Mammograms

docs.abstract: Employers and health plans are offering women monetary incentives to get frequent mammograms; measure, while intended to improve health, complicates personal decision and raises risk of overdiagnosis.
docs.snippet: Health plans offer women a variety of incentives to be screened for breast cancer even when scientific guidelines recommend against it.
